### Section 1.1 Introduction to Kinematics

Kinematics is the study of motion without considering the forces that cause it. In this section, we will introduce the basic concepts of kinematics and their importance in the study of dynamics and vibration.

#### 1.1a Basic Concepts

The three fundamental concepts of kinematics are position, velocity, and acceleration. Position is the location of an object in space, and it is described using coordinates. Velocity is the rate of change of position with respect to time, and it is a vector quantity. Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, and it is also a vector quantity.

The position of an object can be described using Cartesian coordinates or polar coordinates. In Cartesian coordinates, the position of an object is represented by the coordinates (x, y, z), where x, y, and z are the distances of the object from the three axes. In polar coordinates, the position of an object is represented by the distance from the origin (r) and the angles (θ, φ) that the object makes with the x, y, and z axes, respectively.

Velocity is a vector quantity that describes the rate of change of position with respect to time. It is represented by the derivative of the position vector with respect to time, denoted by $\frac{d\vec{r}}{dt}$. The magnitude of the velocity vector is the speed of the object, and its direction is the direction of motion.

Acceleration is also a vector quantity that describes the rate of change of velocity with respect to time. It is represented by the derivative of the velocity vector with respect to time, denoted by $\frac{d^2\vec{r}}{dt^2}$. The magnitude of the acceleration vector is the rate of change of speed, and its direction is the direction of the change in velocity.

In addition to these fundamental concepts, kinematics also deals with the different types of motion. Rectilinear motion is motion along a straight line, and it can be described using the concepts of position, velocity, and acceleration. Curvilinear motion is motion along a curved path, and it can be described using the concepts of position, velocity, acceleration, and the curvature of the path. Rotational motion is motion around a fixed axis, and it can be described using the concepts of position, velocity, acceleration, and the angular velocity.

Relative motion is another important concept in kinematics. It describes the motion of one object relative to another object. This is particularly useful in systems where multiple objects are moving, and we want to describe the motion of one object without considering the motion of the other objects.

In the next section, we will explore the applications of kinematics in various fields, such as robotics, biomechanics, and factory automation. ### Subsection 1.1b Types of Motion

In the previous section, we discussed the fundamental concepts of kinematics, including position, velocity, and acceleration. In this section, we will explore the different types of motion that can occur in a system.

#### 1.1b.1 Rectilinear Motion

As mentioned earlier, rectilinear motion is motion along a straight line. This type of motion is commonly seen in objects moving at a constant velocity, such as a car driving down a straight road. The position of an object undergoing rectilinear motion can be described using the equations:

$$
x(t) = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2
$$

$$
v(t) = v_0 + at
$$

$$
a(t) = a
$$

where $x_0$ is the initial position, $v_0$ is the initial velocity, and $a$ is the constant acceleration.

#### 1.1b.2 Curvilinear Motion

Curvilinear motion is motion along a curved path. This type of motion is commonly seen in objects moving in a circular or elliptical path, such as a planet orbiting the sun. The position of an object undergoing curvilinear motion can be described using the equations:

$$
x(t) = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2
$$

$$
v(t) = v_0 + at
$$

$$
a(t) = a
$$

where $x_0$ is the initial position, $v_0$ is the initial velocity, and $a$ is the constant acceleration. However, in curvilinear motion, the acceleration is not constant and can change in both magnitude and direction.

#### 1.1b.3 Rotational Motion

Rotational motion is motion around a fixed axis. This type of motion is commonly seen in objects spinning around a central point, such as a top spinning on its axis. The position of an object undergoing rotational motion can be described using the equations:

$$
\theta(t) = \omega_0t + \frac{1}{2}\alpha t^2
$$

$$
\omega(t) = \omega_0 + \alpha t
$$

$$
\alpha(t) = \alpha
$$

where $\theta_0$ is the initial angle, $\omega_0$ is the initial angular velocity, and $\alpha$ is the constant angular acceleration.

#### 1.1b.4 Oscillatory Motion

Oscillatory motion is motion that repeats itself in a regular pattern. This type of motion is commonly seen in objects oscillating back and forth, such as a pendulum swinging back and forth. The position of an object undergoing oscillatory motion can be described using the equations:

$$
x(t) = x_0 + A\sin(\omega t + \phi)
$$

$$
v(t) = -A\omega\cos(\omega t + \phi)
$$

$$
a(t) = -A\omega^2\sin(\omega t + \phi)
$$

where $x_0$ is the initial position, $A$ is the amplitude, $\omega$ is the angular frequency, and $\phi$ is the phase shift.

#### 1.1b.5 General Motion

In some cases, a system may exhibit a combination of the above types of motion. This is known as general motion. The position of an object undergoing general motion can be described using the equations:

$$
x(t) = x_0 + v_0t + \frac{1}{2}at^2
$$

$$
v(t) = v_0 + at
$$

$$
a(t) = a
$$

where $x_0$ is the initial position, $v_0$ is the initial velocity, and $a$ is the constant acceleration. However, in general motion, the acceleration may not be constant and can change in both magnitude and direction.

In the next section, we will explore the equations of motion for each type of motion and how they can be used to analyze and predict the behavior of a system.

### Subsection 1.2a Definition and Examples

In the previous section, we discussed the kinematic equations that describe the motion of a system. In this section, we will focus on rectilinear motion, which is motion along a straight line.

#### 1.2a.1 Definition of Rectilinear Motion

Rectilinear motion is a type of motion where an object moves along a straight line. This type of motion is often described using the kinematic equations, which relate the position, velocity, and acceleration of an object over time.

#### 1.2a.2 Examples of Rectilinear Motion

One common example of rectilinear motion is the motion of a car on a straight road. The car's position, velocity, and acceleration can be described using the kinematic equations. For example, if we know the car's initial position and velocity, we can use the position equation to calculate its position at any given time.

Another example of rectilinear motion is the motion of a pendulum. The pendulum's position, velocity, and acceleration can also be described using the kinematic equations. However, in this case, the motion is not constant, as the pendulum swings back and forth.

#### 1.2a.3 Applications of Rectilinear Motion

Rectilinear motion has many applications in engineering and physics. For example, in mechanical engineering, the motion of a car on a straight road can be used to design a car's engine and transmission system. In physics, the motion of a pendulum can be used to study the effects of gravity and friction on a system.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of velocity and its relationship with rectilinear motion.

### Conclusion

In this chapter, we have explored the fundamental concepts of kinematics, which is the study of motion without considering the forces that cause it. We have learned about the different types of motion, including rectilinear motion, curvilinear motion, and rotational motion. We have also discussed the concept of velocity and its relationship with displacement and time. Additionally, we have delved into the concept of acceleration and its relationship with velocity and time. These concepts are crucial in understanding the dynamics and vibrations of systems.

Kinematics is a fundamental aspect of dynamics and vibrations, as it provides the necessary tools to describe the motion of a system. By understanding the different types of motion and their relationships with velocity and acceleration, we can better understand the behavior of systems under different conditions. This knowledge is essential in various fields, including mechanical engineering, civil engineering, and aerospace engineering.

In the next chapter, we will build upon the concepts learned in this chapter and explore the relationship between kinematics and dynamics. We will also introduce the concept of vibrations and how they are affected by the motion of a system. By the end of this book, readers will have a comprehensive understanding of dynamics and vibrations and their applications in various fields.

### Subsection 1.2b Equations of Rectilinear Motion

In the previous section, we discussed the concept of rectilinear motion and provided some examples. In this section, we will explore the equations that govern rectilinear motion.

#### 1.2b.1 The Position Equation

The position equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's position, velocity, and acceleration. It is given by:

$$
v = u + at
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, $a$ is the acceleration, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{dv}{dt} = a
$$

#### 1.2b.2 The Velocity Equation

The velocity equation is another fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's velocity, acceleration, and displacement. It is given by:

$$
v = u + at
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, $a$ is the acceleration, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{dv}{dt} = a
$$

#### 1.2b.3 The Acceleration Equation

The acceleration equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's acceleration, velocity, and displacement. It is given by:

$$
a = \frac{v - u}{t}
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{da}{dt} = \frac{1}{m}\left(\frac{dv}{dt} - a\right)
$$

where $m$ is the mass of the object.

#### 1.2b.4 The Displacement Equation

The displacement equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's displacement, velocity, and acceleration. It is given by:

$$
s = \frac{1}{2}(v + u)t
$$

where $s$ is the displacement, $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{ds}{dt} = \frac{1}{2}(v + u)
$$

#### 1.2b.5 The Velocity-Time Equation

The velocity-time equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's velocity and time. It is given by:

$$
v = u + at
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, $a$ is the acceleration, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{dv}{dt} = a
$$

#### 1.2b.6 The Acceleration-Time Equation

The acceleration-time equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's acceleration and time. It is given by:

$$
a = \frac{v - u}{t}
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{da}{dt} = \frac{1}{m}\left(\frac{dv}{dt} - a\right)
$$

where $m$ is the mass of the object.

#### 1.2b.7 The Displacement-Time Equation

The displacement-time equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's displacement and time. It is given by:

$$
s = \frac{1}{2}(v + u)t
$$

where $s$ is the displacement, $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{ds}{dt} = \frac{1}{2}(v + u)
$$

#### 1.2b.8 The Velocity-Displacement Equation

The velocity-displacement equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's velocity and displacement. It is given by:

$$
v = \sqrt{u^2 + 2as}
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, $a$ is the acceleration, and $s$ is the displacement.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{dv}{ds} = \sqrt{\frac{u^2 + 2as}{s}}
$$

#### 1.2b.9 The Acceleration-Displacement Equation

The acceleration-displacement equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's acceleration and displacement. It is given by:

$$
a = \frac{v - u}{s}
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $s$ is the displacement.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{da}{ds} = \frac{1}{s}\left(\frac{v - u}{s}\right)
$$

#### 1.2b.10 The Displacement-Velocity Equation

The displacement-velocity equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's displacement and velocity. It is given by:

$$
s = \frac{v^2 - u^2}{2a}
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $a$ is the acceleration.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{ds}{dv} = \frac{v - u}{2a}
$$

#### 1.2b.11 The Acceleration-Velocity Equation

The acceleration-velocity equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's acceleration and velocity. It is given by:

$$
a = \frac{v - u}{t}
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{da}{dv} = \frac{1}{t}\left(\frac{v - u}{t}\right)
$$

#### 1.2b.12 The Displacement-Acceleration Equation

The displacement-acceleration equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's displacement and acceleration. It is given by:

$$
s = \frac{1}{2}at^2
$$

where $s$ is the displacement, $a$ is the acceleration, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{ds}{da} = \frac{1}{2}t^2
$$

#### 1.2b.13 The Velocity-Acceleration Equation

The velocity-acceleration equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's velocity and acceleration. It is given by:

$$
v = u + at
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, $a$ is the acceleration, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{dv}{da} = t
$$

#### 1.2b.14 The Displacement-Velocity-Time Equation

The displacement-velocity-time equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's displacement, velocity, and time. It is given by:

$$
s = \frac{1}{2}(v + u)t
$$

where $s$ is the displacement, $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{ds}{d(v + u)} = \frac{1}{2}t
$$

#### 1.2b.15 The Acceleration-Velocity-Time Equation

The acceleration-velocity-time equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's acceleration, velocity, and time. It is given by:

$$
a = \frac{v - u}{t}
$$

where $a$ is the acceleration, $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{da}{d(v - u)} = \frac{1}{t}
$$

#### 1.2b.16 The Displacement-Acceleration-Time Equation

The displacement-acceleration-time equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's displacement, acceleration, and time. It is given by:

$$
s = \frac{1}{2}at^2
$$

where $s$ is the displacement, $a$ is the acceleration, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{ds}{da} = \frac{1}{2}t^2
$$

The velocity-time-acceleration equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's velocity, time, and acceleration. It is given by:

$$
v = u + at
$$

where $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, $a$ is the acceleration, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{dv}{da} = t
$$

#### 1.2b.18 The Displacement-Velocity-Acceleration Equation

The displacement-velocity-acceleration equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's displacement, velocity, and acceleration. It is given by:

$$
s = \frac{1}{2}(v + u)t
$$

where $s$ is the displacement, $v$ is the final velocity, $u$ is the initial velocity, and $t$ is the time interval.

This equation can also be written in differential form as:

$$
\frac{ds}{d(v + u)} = \frac{1}{2}t
$$

#### 1.2b.19 The Acceleration-Velocity-Displacement Equation

The acceleration-velocity-displacement equation is a fundamental equation in kinematics that describes the relationship between an object's acceleration, velocity, and displacement. It is given by:

$$

### Subsection 1.2c Applications of Rectilinear Motion

In this section, we will explore some applications of rectilinear motion in various fields.

#### 1.2c.1 Motion of a Spacecraft

One of the applications of rectilinear motion is in visualizing the rotation of a spacecraft in orbit. This is achieved through Poinsot's construction, which is a geometric representation of the rotation of a spacecraft. The construction is based on the equations of rectilinear motion and is used to visualize the orientation of the spacecraft in space.

#### 1.2c.2 Motion of a Robot Arm

Another application of rectilinear motion is in the control of a robot arm. The arm can be modeled as a kinematic chain, where each joint represents a link in the chain. The equations of rectilinear motion are used to control the motion of the arm, allowing it to perform complex tasks.

#### 1.2c.3 Motion of a Vehicle

Rectilinear motion is also used in the design and control of vehicles. For example, in the design of a car, the equations of rectilinear motion are used to determine the motion of the car under various conditions. In the control of a car, these equations are used to determine the appropriate control inputs to achieve a desired motion.

#### 1.2c.4 Motion of a Particle in a Fluid

Rectilinear motion is also used in the study of fluid dynamics. In particular, it is used to model the motion of a particle in a fluid. The equations of rectilinear motion are used to determine the trajectory of the particle, which can then be used to study the behavior of the fluid.

#### 1.2c.5 Motion of a Point on a Curve

Rectilinear motion is also used in the study of differential geometry. In particular, it is used to study the motion of a point on a curve. The equations of rectilinear motion are used to determine the velocity and acceleration of the point, which can then be used to study the curvature of the curve.

#### 1.2c.6 Motion of a Point in Space

Finally, rectilinear motion is used in the study of celestial mechanics. In particular, it is used to study the motion of a point in space, such as a planet or a satellite. The equations of rectilinear motion are used to determine the trajectory of the point, which can then be used to study the gravitational interactions between the point and other objects in space.

In conclusion, rectilinear motion is a fundamental concept in kinematics with a wide range of applications. It is used in various fields, including spacecraft control, robotics, vehicle design, fluid dynamics, differential geometry, and celestial mechanics. Understanding the equations of rectilinear motion is crucial for understanding and controlling the motion of objects in these fields.

### Subsection 1.3a Introduction to Curvilinear Motion

In the previous sections, we have explored the theory and applications of rectilinear motion. However, many real-world phenomena involve motion along curved paths. In this section, we will introduce the concept of curvilinear motion and discuss its applications.

#### 1.3a.1 Definition of Curvilinear Motion

Curvilinear motion is a type of motion in which an object moves along a curved path. This is in contrast to rectilinear motion, where the object moves along a straight line. The path traced by the object in curvilinear motion is described by a curve.

#### 1.3a.2 Applications of Curvilinear Motion

Curvilinear motion has a wide range of applications in various fields. Some of these applications are discussed below.

##### 1.3a.2.1 Motion of a Spacecraft

In the previous section, we discussed the application of rectilinear motion in visualizing the rotation of a spacecraft in orbit. However, in many cases, the path traced by the spacecraft is not a straight line. This is where the concept of curvilinear motion becomes relevant. By studying the curvilinear motion of the spacecraft, we can gain a better understanding of its orientation and position in space.

##### 1.3a.2.2 Motion of a Robot Arm

Similar to the spacecraft, the motion of a robot arm can also be described using curvilinear motion. The arm can move along a curved path, and by studying this motion, we can control the arm to perform complex tasks.

##### 1.3a.2.3 Motion of a Vehicle

The motion of a vehicle, such as a car or a plane, can also be described using curvilinear motion. For example, when a car turns a corner, its path is not a straight line. By studying the curvilinear motion of the car, we can understand its speed, acceleration, and direction at any given point.

##### 1.3a.2.4 Motion of a Point on a Curve

In the study of differential geometry, the motion of a point on a curve is often described using curvilinear motion. By studying the curvilinear motion of the point, we can understand the properties of the curve, such as its curvature and torsion.

In the following sections, we will delve deeper into the theory of curvilinear motion and explore its applications in more detail.




#### 1.3b Polar Coordinates

In the previous sections, we have discussed the concept of curvilinear motion and its applications. In this section, we will introduce another important coordinate system that is often used to describe curvilinear motion - the polar coordinate system.

#### 1.3b.1 Definition of Polar Coordinates

The polar coordinate system is a two-dimensional coordinate system in which each point on a plane is represented by a distance from a fixed point (the pole) and an angle from a fixed ray (the polar axis). The distance from the pole is called the radial coordinate, and the angle from the polar axis is called the angular coordinate.

#### 1.3b.2 Conversion between Polar and Cartesian Coordinates

The polar coordinate system is often used in conjunction with the Cartesian coordinate system. The conversion between the two systems is given by the following equations:

$$
x = r \cos \theta
$$

$$
y = r \sin \theta
$$

where $r$ is the radial coordinate and $\theta$ is the angular coordinate.

#### 1.3b.3 Applications of Polar Coordinates

Polar coordinates have a wide range of applications in various fields. Some of these applications are discussed below.

##### 1.3b.3.1 Motion of a Point on a Circle

The motion of a point on a circle can be easily described using polar coordinates. The radial coordinate remains constant, and the angular coordinate changes linearly with time. This is often used in the study of rotational motion.

##### 1.3b.3.2 Motion of a Point in a Spherical System

In a spherical system, the motion of a point can be described using spherical coordinates. However, in some cases, it is more convenient to use polar coordinates. For example, the motion of a point on a sphere can be described using polar coordinates if the sphere is rotating around a fixed axis.

##### 1.3b.3.3 Motion of a Point in a Cylindrical System

Similar to the spherical system, the motion of a point in a cylindrical system can be described using cylindrical coordinates. However, in some cases, it is more convenient to use polar coordinates. For example, the motion of a point on a cylinder can be described using polar coordinates if the cylinder is rotating around its axis.

##### 1.3b.3.4 Motion of a Point in a Conic Section

The motion of a point in a conic section (ellipse, parabola, or hyperbola) can be described using polar coordinates. The radial coordinate represents the distance from the focus, and the angular coordinate represents the angle from the directrix. This is often used in the study of conic sections.

##### 1.3b.3.5 Motion of a Point in a Spiral

The motion of a point in a spiral can be described using polar coordinates. The radial coordinate represents the distance from the center, and the angular coordinate represents the angle from the initial point. This is often used in the study of spiral motion.

The motion of a point in a helix can be described using polar coordinates. The radial coordinate represents the distance from the center, and the angular coordinate represents the angle from the initial point. This is often used in the study of helical motion.

#### 1.3c Applications of Curvilinear Motion

In the previous sections, we have discussed the concept of curvilinear motion and its applications. In this section, we will delve deeper into the applications of curvilinear motion, focusing on the use of polar coordinates.

#### 1.3c.1 Motion of a Point on a Curved Path

The motion of a point on a curved path can be described using polar coordinates. The radial coordinate changes according to the curvature of the path, and the angular coordinate changes linearly with time. This is often used in the study of trajectories in various fields, such as astrophysics and robotics.

#### 1.3c.2 Motion of a Point in a Three-Dimensional System

In a three-dimensional system, the motion of a point can be described using Cartesian coordinates. However, in some cases, it is more convenient to use polar coordinates. For example, the motion of a point in a three-dimensional system can be described using polar coordinates if the system is symmetric about an axis.

#### 1.3c.3 Motion of a Point in a Central Force Field

The motion of a point in a central force field can be described using polar coordinates. The radial coordinate changes according to the force field, and the angular coordinate changes linearly with time. This is often used in the study of planetary motion and atomic physics.

#### 1.3c.4 Motion of a Point in a Rotating System

The motion of a point in a rotating system can be described using polar coordinates. The radial coordinate remains constant, and the angular coordinate changes linearly with time. This is often used in the study of rotational motion in various fields, such as fluid dynamics and robotics.

#### 1.3c.5 Motion of a Point in a Spherical System

In a spherical system, the motion of a point can be described using spherical coordinates. However, in some cases, it is more convenient to use polar coordinates. For example, the motion of a point on a sphere can be described using polar coordinates if the sphere is rotating around a fixed axis.

#### 1.3c.6 Motion of a Point in a Cylindrical System

Similar to the spherical system, the motion of a point in a cylindrical system can be described using cylindrical coordinates. However, in some cases, it is more convenient to use polar coordinates. For example, the motion of a point on a cylinder can be described using polar coordinates if the cylinder is rotating around a fixed axis.




#### 1.4a Angular Displacement

Angular displacement is a fundamental concept in rotational motion. It is the change in the orientation of a point or a line segment. In the context of rotational motion, it is the angle through which a point or a line segment has been rotated in a specified sense about a specified axis.

#### 1.4a.1 Definition of Angular Displacement

Angular displacement ($\Delta \theta$) is defined as the difference in the angles between the initial and final positions of a point or a line segment. It is measured in radians. The direction of angular displacement is determined by the right-hand rule. If the fingers of the right hand curl in the direction of rotation, the thumb points in the direction of angular displacement.

#### 1.4a.2 Angular Displacement and Angular Velocity

Angular displacement is closely related to angular velocity. The angular velocity ($\omega$) of a point or a line segment is the rate of change of its angular displacement with respect to time. It is measured in radians per second. The relationship between angular displacement and angular velocity is given by the equation:

$$
\Delta \theta = \omega \Delta t
$$

where $\Delta t$ is the time interval.

#### 1.4a.3 Angular Displacement and Angular Acceleration

Angular displacement is also related to angular acceleration. The angular acceleration ($\alpha$) of a point or a line segment is the rate of change of its angular velocity with respect to time. It is measured in radians per second squared. The relationship between angular displacement, angular velocity, and angular acceleration is given by the equations:

$$
\Delta \theta = \frac{1}{2} \alpha \Delta t^2
$$

$$
\omega = \omega_0 + \alpha \Delta t
$$

where $\omega_0$ is the initial angular velocity.

#### 1.4a.4 Angular Displacement and Rotational Motion

Angular displacement plays a crucial role in rotational motion. It is used to describe the motion of a point or a line segment in a rotating system. The equations of rotational motion, such as the equations of motion for a rotating body and the equations of motion for a rotating point, involve angular displacement.

#### 1.4a.5 Angular Displacement and Spherical Harmonics

Angular displacement is also used in the study of spherical harmonics. Spherical harmonics are a set of functions that describe the motion of a point on the surface of a sphere. They are used in various fields, including quantum mechanics and geophysics. The coefficients of the spherical harmonics, known as the spherical harmonic coefficients, are related to the angular displacement of the point.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the concept of angular velocity and its applications in rotational motion.

#### 1.4b Angular Velocity

Angular velocity is a measure of the rate of change of an angle with respect to time. In the context of rotational motion, it is the rate at which a point or a line segment is moving around a circular path. It is a vector quantity, with the direction of the vector along the axis of rotation, following the right-hand rule.

#### 1.4b.1 Definition of Angular Velocity

Angular velocity ($\omega$) is defined as the derivative of the angular displacement ($\theta$) with respect to time:

$$
\omega = \frac{d\theta}{dt}
$$

It is measured in radians per second. The direction of angular velocity is determined by the right-hand rule. If the fingers of the right hand curl in the direction of rotation, the thumb points in the direction of angular velocity.

#### 1.4b.2 Angular Velocity and Angular Acceleration

Angular velocity is closely related to angular acceleration. The angular acceleration ($\alpha$) of a point or a line segment is the rate of change of its angular velocity with respect to time. It is measured in radians per second squared. The relationship between angular velocity and angular acceleration is given by the equation:

$$
\alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt}
$$

#### 1.4b.3 Angular Velocity and Rotational Motion

Angular velocity plays a crucial role in rotational motion. It is used to describe the motion of a point or a line segment in a rotating system. The equations of rotational motion, such as the equations of motion for a rotating body and the equations of motion for a rotating point, involve angular velocity.

#### 1.4b.4 Angular Velocity and Spherical Harmonics

Angular velocity is also used in the study of spherical harmonics. Spherical harmonics are a set of functions that describe the motion of a point on the surface of a sphere. They are used in various fields, including quantum mechanics and geophysics. The coefficients of the spherical harmonics, known as the spherical harmonic coefficients, are related to the angular velocity of the point.

#### 1.4b.5 Angular Velocity and Rotational Inertia

Angular velocity is also related to rotational inertia. The rotational inertia of a point or a line segment is a measure of its resistance to changes in its rotational motion. It is defined as the sum of the products of the mass of each particle and the square of its distance from the axis of rotation. The relationship between angular velocity and rotational inertia is given by the equation:

$$
I = \int r^2 dm
$$

where $I$ is the rotational inertia, $r$ is the distance from the axis of rotation, and $dm$ is the differential mass.

#### 1.4b Angular Velocity and Acceleration

Angular velocity and acceleration are fundamental concepts in rotational motion. They describe the rate of change of angular displacement and angular velocity, respectively. 

#### 1.4b.1 Angular Velocity

Angular velocity ($\omega$) is the rate of change of angular displacement with respect to time. It is a vector quantity, with the direction of the vector along the axis of rotation, following the right-hand rule. The magnitude of the angular velocity vector is equal to the rate of change of the angle of rotation. 

The angular velocity vector can be expressed as a linear mapping, or an angular velocity tensor, "W" = "W"("t") defined by:

$$
W =
\begin{pmatrix}
0 & -\omega_z & \omega_y \\
\omega_z & 0 & -\omega_x \\
-\omega_y & \omega_x & 0 \\
\end{pmatrix}
$$

This tensor acts as $(\boldsymbol\omega \times)$:

$$
\frac {dA}{dt} 
&= \begin{bmatrix} 
\dfrac{d\mathbf{e}_1}{dt} &
\dfrac{d\mathbf{e}_2}{dt} &
\dfrac{d\mathbf{e}_3}{dt} 
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} 
\omega \times \mathbf{e}_1 & 
\omega \times \mathbf{e}_2 & 
\omega \times \mathbf{e}_3 
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= \begin{bmatrix} 
W \mathbf{e}_1 & 
W\mathbf{e}_2 & 
W \mathbf{e}_3 
\end{bmatrix} \\
&= W A,
$$

which holds even if "A"("t") does not rotate uniformly. Therefore, the angular velocity tensor is:

$$
W = \frac {dA}{dt} A^{\mathsf{T}},
$$

where $A^{\mathsf{T}}$ is the transpose of the orientation matrix "A".

#### 1.4b.2 Angular Acceleration

Angular acceleration ($\alpha$) is the rate of change of angular velocity with respect to time. It is a vector quantity, with the direction of the vector along the axis of rotation, following the right-hand rule. The magnitude of the angular acceleration vector is equal to the rate of change of the magnitude of the angular velocity vector.

The relationship between angular acceleration and angular velocity is given by the equation:

$$
\alpha = \frac {d\omega}{dt}.
$$

In three dimensions, the orbital angular acceleration is the rate at which the three-dimensional orbital angular velocity vector changes with time. The instantaneous angular velocity vector $\boldsymbol\omega$ at any point in time is given by:

$$
\boldsymbol\omega = \boldsymbol\omega_0 + \int_0^t \alpha(t') dt',
$$

where $\boldsymbol\omega_0$ is the initial angular velocity.

#### 1.4b.3 Angular Velocity and Acceleration in Rotational Motion

In rotational motion, the angular velocity and acceleration play a crucial role in describing the motion of a point or a line segment. The equations of motion can be expressed in terms of these quantities, providing a powerful tool for analyzing rotational motion.

For example, the equation of motion for a point moving in a rotating frame can be written as:

$$
\frac {d^2\mathbf{r}}{dt^2} = \omega \times (\omega \times \mathbf{r}) + \alpha \times \mathbf{r},
$$

where $\mathbf{r}$ is the position vector of the point, and $\omega$ and $\alpha$ are the angular velocity and acceleration, respectively. This equation describes the translational motion of the point in the rotating frame.

Similarly, the equation of motion for a line segment moving in a rotating frame can be written as:

$$
\frac {d^2\mathbf{r}}{dt^2} = \omega \times (\omega \times \mathbf{r}) + \alpha \times \mathbf{r},
$$

where $\mathbf{r}$ is the position vector of the line segment, and $\omega$ and $\alpha$ are the angular velocity and acceleration, respectively. This equation describes the rotational motion of the line segment in the rotating frame.

In the next section, we will explore these equations in more detail, and discuss their applications in various physical systems.

#### 1.4c Rotational Motion Examples

In this section, we will explore some examples of rotational motion to further illustrate the concepts of angular velocity and acceleration.

##### Example 1: Uniform Circular Motion

Consider a particle moving in a circular path of radius $r$ at a constant angular velocity $\omega$. The position vector of the particle is given by $\mathbf{r} = r\mathbf{\hat{r}}$, where $\mathbf{\hat{r}}$ is the unit vector along the radius.

The velocity of the particle is given by $\frac{d\mathbf{r}}{dt} = \omega r\mathbf{\hat{\theta}}$, where $\mathbf{\hat{\theta}}$ is the unit vector along the tangent to the circle. The acceleration of the particle is given by $\frac{d^2\mathbf{r}}{dt^2} = \omega^2 r\mathbf{\hat{r}}$.

The angular acceleration is zero, since the angular velocity is constant. This is consistent with the fact that the particle is moving at a constant speed in a circular path.

##### Example 2: Non-uniform Circular Motion

Now, consider a particle moving in a circular path of radius $r$ at a non-constant angular velocity $\omega(t)$. The position vector of the particle is still given by $\mathbf{r} = r\mathbf{\hat{r}}$, but the velocity and acceleration are now given by:

$$
\frac{d\mathbf{r}}{dt} = \omega(t) r\mathbf{\hat{\theta}},
$$

$$
\frac{d^2\mathbf{r}}{dt^2} = \frac{d\omega}{dt} r\mathbf{\hat{r}} + \omega(t)^2 r\mathbf{\hat{r}}.
$$

The acceleration is no longer constant, reflecting the fact that the particle is now moving at a varying speed in a circular path.

##### Example 3: Rotational Motion in a Frame

Consider a frame rotating at a constant angular velocity $\omega$ about the $z$-axis. The orientation matrix $A(t)$ of the frame is given by:

$$
A(t) = \begin{bmatrix}
\mathbf{\hat{x}}(t) & \mathbf{\hat{y}}(t) & \mathbf{\hat{z}}(t)
\end{bmatrix},
$$

where $\mathbf{\hat{x}}(t)$, $\mathbf{\hat{y}}(t)$, and $\mathbf{\hat{z}}(t)$ are the columns of the matrix, and are the moving orthonormal coordinate vectors of the frame.

The angular velocity tensor $W(t)$ of the frame is given by:

$$
W(t) = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & -\omega\mathbf{\hat{z}}(t) & \omega\mathbf{\hat{y}}(t) \\
\omega\mathbf{\hat{z}}(t) & 0 & -\omega\mathbf{\hat{x}}(t) \\
-\omega\mathbf{\hat{y}}(t) & \omega\mathbf{\hat{x}}(t) & 0
\end{bmatrix}.
$$

The angular acceleration of the frame is given by $\frac{dW}{dt}$. This example illustrates how the concepts of angular velocity and acceleration can be applied to analyze the motion of a rotating frame.




#### 1.4c Rotational Kinematics

Rotational kinematics is the study of the motion of objects that are rotating or spinning. It is a crucial aspect of dynamics and vibration, as many physical systems, such as engines, turbines, and machines, involve rotational motion. 

#### 1.4c.1 Rotational Motion

Rotational motion is the movement of an object around a fixed axis. The object's position in space is described by its orientation, which can be represented by an orientation matrix "A". The rate of change of this orientation is described by the angular velocity vector $\omega$. 

The orientation matrix "A"("t") satisfies the differential equation:

$$
\frac {dA}{dt} = W A,
$$

where $W$ is the angular velocity tensor. This equation describes the rotation of the object in space.

#### 1.4c.2 Rotational Velocity

Rotational velocity is the rate of change of the angle of rotation. It is a vector quantity, with the direction of the vector along the axis of rotation, following the right-hand rule. The magnitude of the rotational velocity vector is equal to the rate of change of the angle of rotation.

The relationship between rotational velocity and angular velocity is given by the equation:

$$
v = r \omega,
$$

where $v$ is the linear velocity, $r$ is the radius of rotation, and $\omega$ is the angular velocity.

#### 1.4c.3 Rotational Acceleration

Rotational acceleration is the rate of change of rotational velocity with respect to time. It is a vector quantity, with the direction of the vector along the axis of rotation, following the right-hand rule. The magnitude of the rotational acceleration vector is equal to the rate of change of the magnitude of the rotational velocity vector.

The relationship between rotational acceleration and angular acceleration is given by the equation:

$$
a = r \alpha,
$$

where $a$ is the linear acceleration, $r$ is the radius of rotation, and $\alpha$ is the angular acceleration.

#### 1.4c.4 Rotational Kinematics Equations

The equations of rotational kinematics are analogous to the equations of linear kinematics. They are as follows:

1. Rotational displacement: $\Delta \theta = \int \omega \, dt$
2. Final rotational velocity: $v_f = v_0 + \int a \, dt$
3. Rotational velocity squared: $v_f^2 = v_0^2 + 2 \int v \, a \, dt$
4. Rotational displacement: $\Delta \theta = \int \frac{v}{r} \, dt$
5. Final rotational velocity: $v_f = v_0 + \int \frac{a}{r} \, dt$
6. Rotational velocity squared: $v_f^2 = v_0^2 + 2 \int \frac{v \, a}{r} \, dt$

where $\Delta \theta$ is the rotational displacement, $v_f$ is the final rotational velocity, $v_0$ is the initial rotational velocity, $a$ is the rotational acceleration, $v$ is the linear velocity, $r$ is the radius of rotation, and $t$ is time.

These equations are fundamental to the study of rotational motion and are used in a wide range of applications, from the design of rotating machinery to the analysis of celestial bodies.




#### 1.5a Definition of Rigid Bodies

A rigid body, in the context of classical mechanics, is a solid body in which deformation is zero or negligible. This means that the distance between any two given points on a rigid body remains constant in time, regardless of external forces or moments exerted on it. 

In the study of special relativity, a perfectly rigid body does not exist; and objects can only be assumed to be rigid if they are not moving near the speed of light. In quantum mechanics, a rigid body is usually thought of as a collection of point masses. For instance, molecules (consisting of the point masses: electrons and nuclei) are often seen as rigid bodies (see classification of molecules as rigid rotors).

#### 1.5a.1 Kinematics of Rigid Bodies

The kinematics of rigid bodies is concerned with the study of the motion of these bodies. The position of a rigid body is the position of all the particles of which it is composed. To simplify the description of this position, we exploit the property that the body is rigid, namely that all its particles maintain the same distance relative to each other. If the body is rigid, it is sufficient to describe the position of at least three non-collinear particles. This makes it possible to reconstruct the position of all the other particles, provided that their time-invariant position relative to the three selected particles is known. However, typically a different, mathematically more convenient, but equivalent approach is used. The position of the whole body is represented by:

$$
\mathbf{r}(t) = \sum_{i=1}^{n} \mathbf{r}_i(t),
$$

where $\mathbf{r}_i(t)$ is the position vector of the $i$-th particle at time $t$.

The linear position can be represented by a vector with its tail at an arbitrary reference point in space (the origin of a chosen coordinate system) and its tip at an arbitrary point on the body. The angular position, on the other hand, is represented by a vector with its tail at the center of rotation and its tip at an arbitrary point on the body.

In the following sections, we will delve deeper into the kinematics of rigid bodies, exploring concepts such as linear and angular velocity, acceleration, and momentum. We will also discuss the equations of motion for rigid bodies, and how these equations can be used to analyze and predict the behavior of physical systems.

#### 1.5a.2 Rotational Kinematics

Rotational kinematics is the study of the motion of rigid bodies that are rotating or spinning. It is a crucial aspect of the kinematics of rigid bodies, as it allows us to understand how these bodies move in space.

##### Rotational Motion

Rotational motion is the movement of a rigid body around a fixed axis. The orientation of the body in space is described by its rotation matrix $R(t)$, which is a 3x3 matrix that describes the orientation of the body at time $t$. The rotation matrix is defined as:

$$
R(t) = \begin{bmatrix}
\cos \theta & \sin \theta & 0 \\
- \sin \theta & \cos \theta & 0 \\
0 & 0 & 1
\end{bmatrix},
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle of rotation around the axis.

The orientation of the body changes over time according to the differential equation:

$$
\frac{dR}{dt} = \omega \times R,
$$

where $\omega$ is the angular velocity vector, and $\times$ denotes the cross product.

##### Rotational Velocity

Rotational velocity is the rate of change of the angle of rotation. It is a vector quantity, with the direction of the vector along the axis of rotation, following the right-hand rule. The magnitude of the rotational velocity vector is equal to the rate of change of the angle of rotation.

The relationship between rotational velocity and angular velocity is given by the equation:

$$
v = r \omega,
$$

where $v$ is the linear velocity, $r$ is the radius of rotation, and $\omega$ is the angular velocity.

##### Rotational Acceleration

Rotational acceleration is the rate of change of rotational velocity with respect to time. It is a vector quantity, with the direction of the vector along the axis of rotation, following the right-hand rule. The magnitude of the rotational acceleration vector is equal to the rate of change of the magnitude of the rotational velocity vector.

The relationship between rotational acceleration and angular acceleration is given by the equation:

$$
a = r \alpha,
$$

where $a$ is the linear acceleration, $r$ is the radius of rotation, and $\alpha$ is the angular acceleration.

##### Rotational Kinematics Equations

The equations of rotational kinematics can be summarized as follows:

$$
\frac{dR}{dt} = \omega \times R,
$$

$$
\frac{d\omega}{dt} = \alpha \times \omega,
$$

$$
\frac{d\theta}{dt} = \omega \cdot \omega,
$$

where $R$ is the rotation matrix, $\omega$ is the angular velocity vector, $\alpha$ is the angular acceleration vector, and $\theta$ is the angle of rotation.

These equations describe the motion of a rigid body in space, and they are fundamental to the study of rotational kinematics.

#### 1.5a.3 Applications of Rigid Bodies

The study of rigid bodies and their kinematics has a wide range of applications in various fields. In this section, we will explore some of these applications, focusing on the dynamics of a spinning top and the equations of motion for a rigid body.

##### Dynamics of a Spinning Top

The dynamics of a spinning top is a classic example of the application of rigid body kinematics. A top is a toy that spins around its axis due to the force of gravity. The top can be modeled as a rigid body rotating around a fixed axis.

The angular velocity of the top, $\omega$, is given by the equation:

$$
\omega = \frac{v}{r},
$$

where $v$ is the linear velocity of the top and $r$ is the radius of rotation. The linear velocity $v$ can be calculated using the equation:

$$
v = \frac{d\theta}{dt},
$$

where $\theta$ is the angle of rotation and $t$ is time.

The angular acceleration of the top, $\alpha$, is given by the equation:

$$
\alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt},
$$

which can be calculated using the equation:

$$
\alpha = \frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2}.
$$

These equations can be used to analyze the motion of the top and predict its behavior.

##### Equations of Motion for a Rigid Body

The equations of motion for a rigid body are given by the Euler's equations of motion, which can be written in matrix form as:

$$
\frac{d}{dt} \begin{bmatrix}

\omega \\

\alpha

\end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}

0 & I \\

-I & 0

\end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix}

\omega \\

\alpha

\end{bmatrix},
$$

where $I$ is the moment of inertia matrix. These equations describe the rotational motion of the body and can be used to analyze the behavior of the body under various conditions.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of vibrations and how they relate to the kinematics of rigid bodies.




#### 1.5b Rotation and Translation

The motion of a rigid body can be described by two types of motion: rotation and translation. Rotation is the motion of a body about a fixed axis, while translation is the motion of a body along a straight line. In the case of a rigid body, these two types of motion are coupled, as the rotation of one part of the body can cause a translation of another part.

#### 1.5b.1 Rotation of Rigid Bodies

The rotation of a rigid body can be described by the angular velocity, $\omega$, which is the rate of change of the angular position. The angular velocity is a vector quantity, and its direction is perpendicular to the plane of rotation. The magnitude of the angular velocity is equal to the rate of change of the angular position.

The angular velocity can be represented as:

$$
\omega = \frac{d\theta}{dt},
$$

where $\theta$ is the angular position and $t$ is time.

The angular acceleration, $\alpha$, is the rate of change of the angular velocity. It is also a vector quantity, and its direction is perpendicular to the plane of rotation. The magnitude of the angular acceleration is equal to the rate of change of the angular velocity.

The angular acceleration can be represented as:

$$
\alpha = \frac{d\omega}{dt}.
$$

The angular acceleration can be related to the angular velocity and the angular position by the second-order differential equation:

$$
\alpha = \frac{d^2\theta}{dt^2}.
$$

#### 1.5b.2 Translation of Rigid Bodies

The translation of a rigid body can be described by the linear velocity, $v$, which is the rate of change of the linear position. The linear velocity is a vector quantity, and its direction is along the line of translation. The magnitude of the linear velocity is equal to the rate of change of the linear position.

The linear velocity can be represented as:

$$
v = \frac{dx}{dt},
$$

where $x$ is the linear position and $t$ is time.

The linear acceleration, $a$, is the rate of change of the linear velocity. It is also a vector quantity, and its direction is along the line of translation. The magnitude of the linear acceleration is equal to the rate of change of the linear velocity.

The linear acceleration can be represented as:

$$
a = \frac{dv}{dt}.
$$

The linear acceleration can be related to the linear velocity and the linear position by the second-order differential equation:

$$
a = \frac{d^2x}{dt^2}.
$$

In the next section, we will discuss the equations of motion for a rigid body, which describe the relationship between the forces and moments acting on the body and its motion.

#### 1.5b.3 Coupled Rotation and Translation

The motion of a rigid body is a combination of rotation and translation. The rotation and translation are coupled, meaning that the rotation of one part of the body can cause a translation of another part. This coupling is described by the equations of motion, which relate the forces and moments acting on the body to its motion.

The equations of motion for a rigid body can be written as:

$$
\begin{aligned}
I\omega &= M \\
M &= I\alpha \\
F &= ma \\
\end{aligned}
$$

where $I$ is the moment of inertia, $M$ is the moment, $F$ is the force, $m$ is the mass, $\omega$ is the angular velocity, $\alpha$ is the angular acceleration, $a$ is the linear acceleration, and $v$ is the linear velocity.

These equations show that the angular acceleration is related to the moment, and the linear acceleration is related to the force. This means that the rotation of the body is caused by the moment acting on the body, and the translation of the body is caused by the force acting on the body.

The equations of motion also show that the moment of inertia and the mass are important parameters in the motion of a rigid body. The moment of inertia is a measure of the resistance of the body to rotational motion, and the mass is a measure of the resistance of the body to translational motion.

In the next section, we will discuss the applications of these equations in the study of the motion of rigid bodies.




#### 1.5c Applications in Dynamics

The study of kinematics of rigid bodies has numerous applications in the field of dynamics. In this section, we will explore some of these applications, focusing on factory automation infrastructure and the use of the Extended Kalman filter.

#### 1.5c.1 Factory Automation Infrastructure

Factory automation infrastructure relies heavily on the principles of kinematics. The movement of machines and equipment in a factory can be modeled as the motion of rigid bodies. The kinematic equations can be used to predict the trajectory of these bodies, which is crucial for the design and control of automated systems.

For example, consider a robotic arm in a factory. The arm can be modeled as a kinematic chain, a series of rigid bodies connected by joints that allow relative motion. The kinematic equations can be used to calculate the position and orientation of the arm at any given time, based on the initial conditions and the velocities and accelerations of the joints. This information can then be used to control the arm's movement, allowing it to perform precise tasks.

#### 1.5c.2 Extended Kalman Filter

The Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) is a powerful tool for state estimation in dynamic systems. It is an extension of the Kalman filter, which is used for state estimation in linear systems. The EKF can handle nonlinear systems by linearizing the system model and measurement model around the current estimate.

The EKF uses the principles of kinematics to estimate the state of a dynamic system. The system model, which describes the evolution of the system state over time, is often expressed in terms of the kinematic equations. The measurement model, which relates the system state to the measurements, can also involve kinematic equations.

The EKF operates in two steps: prediction and update. In the prediction step, the EKF uses the system model to predict the state at the next time step. In the update step, it uses the measurement model and the measurements to correct the predicted state. This process is repeated at each time step, resulting in an estimate of the system state that is optimal in the mean square error sense.

The EKF has been widely used in various fields, including robotics, navigation, and control systems. Its ability to handle nonlinear systems makes it particularly useful in these areas, where the system dynamics are often nonlinear.

In the next section, we will delve deeper into the theory of the Extended Kalman Filter, exploring its mathematical foundations and its applications in more detail.




#### 1.6a Review of Key Concepts

In this section, we will review some of the key concepts that we have covered in this chapter. These concepts are fundamental to understanding the dynamics and vibrations of systems, and they will be used extensively in the subsequent chapters.

#### 1.6a.1 Kinematics of Rigid Bodies

We began this chapter by discussing the kinematics of rigid bodies. A rigid body is an idealization of a physical body in which deformation is neglected. The motion of a rigid body can be described by its translation and rotation. The translation of a rigid body is described by its position vector, which is a vector from a fixed reference point to the body. The rotation of a rigid body is described by its orientation, which is a set of three angles that define the orientation of the body.

#### 1.6a.2 Motion of Rigid Bodies

The motion of a rigid body can be described by its velocity and acceleration. The velocity of a rigid body is the derivative of its position vector with respect to time. The acceleration of a rigid body is the derivative of its velocity with respect to time. These derivatives can be calculated using the chain rule, which allows us to express them in terms of the derivatives of the position vector and orientation.

#### 1.6a.3 Kinematic Equations

The kinematic equations are a set of equations that relate the position, velocity, and acceleration of a rigid body. These equations are derived from the definitions of velocity and acceleration, and they are used to describe the motion of rigid bodies. The kinematic equations are:

$$
\begin{align*}
v(t) &= \frac{dx(t)}{dt} \\
a(t) &= \frac{dv(t)}{dt} \\
a(t) &= \frac{d^2x(t)}{dt^2}
\end{align*}
$$

where $v(t)$ is the velocity of the body, $a(t)$ is the acceleration of the body, and $x(t)$ is the position of the body.

#### 1.6a.4 Applications in Dynamics

The study of kinematics of rigid bodies has numerous applications in the field of dynamics. In this section, we have explored some of these applications, focusing on factory automation infrastructure and the use of the Extended Kalman filter.

#### 1.6a.5 Extended Kalman Filter

The Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) is a powerful tool for state estimation in dynamic systems. It is an extension of the Kalman filter, which is used for state estimation in linear systems. The EKF can handle nonlinear systems by linearizing the system model and measurement model around the current estimate.

The EKF uses the principles of kinematics to estimate the state of a dynamic system. The system model, which describes the evolution of the system state over time, is often expressed in terms of the kinematic equations. The measurement model, which relates the system state to the measurements, can also involve kinematic equations.

The EKF operates in two steps: prediction and update. In the prediction step, the EKF uses the system model to predict the state at the next time step. In the update step, it uses the measurement model and the measurements to correct the predicted state. This process is repeated at each time step, allowing the EKF to track the state of the system over time.

#### 1.6b Problem Solving Session

In this section, we will apply the concepts we have learned in this chapter to solve some problems. This will help us understand the practical applications of kinematics and how it is used in the field of dynamics.

#### 1.6b.1 Problem Solving Technique

Before we start solving problems, let's discuss a problem-solving technique that will be useful in this course. This technique is known as the "divide and conquer" approach. In this approach, we break down a complex problem into smaller, more manageable parts. We then solve each part individually and combine the solutions to solve the original problem.

#### 1.6b.2 Example Problem

Let's apply the "divide and conquer" approach to solve the following problem:

A car is traveling at a constant speed of 60 miles per hour. If it takes 2 hours to reach its destination, how far is the destination from the starting point?

##### Solution

We can break down this problem into two parts:

1. How long does it take to travel 1 mile at a speed of 60 miles per hour?
2. How many miles does it take to travel 2 hours at a speed of 60 miles per hour?

We can solve the first part by dividing the speed by the distance:

$$
\frac{60\text{ miles per hour}}{1\text{ mile}} = 60\text{ hours per mile}
$$

This means it takes 60 hours to travel 1 mile at a speed of 60 miles per hour.

We can solve the second part by multiplying the speed by the time:

$$
60\text{ miles per hour} \times 2\text{ hours} = 120\text{ miles}
$$

This means it takes 120 miles to travel 2 hours at a speed of 60 miles per hour.

Therefore, the destination is 120 miles from the starting point.

#### 1.6b.3 Generalizing the Problem Solving Technique

We can generalize this problem-solving technique to solve more complex problems. For example, if we are given a function $f(x)$ and we want to find the value of $x$ that makes $f(x) = 0$, we can break down the problem into two parts:

1. What is the value of $x$ that makes $f'(x) = 0$?
2. If we know the value of $x$ that makes $f'(x) = 0$, how can we find the value of $x$ that makes $f(x) = 0$?

By solving these two parts, we can find the value of $x$ that makes $f(x) = 0$.

#### 1.6b.4 Application in Dynamics

The "divide and conquer" approach is particularly useful in the field of dynamics, where we often encounter complex systems with many interacting components. By breaking down the system into smaller, more manageable parts, we can better understand its behavior and predict its response to different inputs.

#### 1.6c.2 Q&A

1. Q: How do we know when to break down a problem into smaller parts?
2. A: The "divide and conquer" approach is most effective when dealing with complex problems. By breaking down the problem into smaller, more manageable parts, we can solve each part individually and then combine the solutions to solve the original problem.

3. Q: Can we use this problem-solving technique for any type of problem?
4. A: The "divide and conquer" approach can be applied to a wide range of problems, not just mathematical ones. It can be used in any situation where a problem seems too complex to solve all at once.

5. Q: How does the problem-solving technique change when dealing with functions?
6. A: When dealing with functions, we need to consider the derivative of the function in addition to the function itself. This is because the derivative of a function can provide valuable information about the function's behavior, which can help us solve the problem.

6. Q: Can you provide an example of a problem where this technique can be used to find the value of a variable?
7. A: One example is finding the value of $x$ that makes $f(x) = 0$. By finding the value of $x$ that makes $f'(x) = 0$, we can then use the intermediate value theorem to determine the value of $x$ that makes $f(x) = 0$.

## Chapter 2: Momentum Formulation for Systems of Particles:




### Section: 2.1 Linear Momentum:

In the previous chapter, we introduced the concept of linear momentum and its importance in the study of dynamics and vibrations. In this section, we will delve deeper into the topic and explore the conservation of linear momentum.

#### 2.1b Conservation of Linear Momentum

The conservation of linear momentum is a fundamental principle in classical mechanics that states that the total linear momentum of a closed system remains constant unless acted upon by an external force. This principle is mathematically expressed as:

$$
\sum_{i} m_i v_i = constant
$$

where $m_i$ and $v_i$ are the mass and velocity of the $i$th particle in the system, respectively.

$$

It depends on both the mass of the object and its distribution of mass around the axis of rotation. The angular velocity, $\boldsymbol{\omega}$, is the rate of change of the angle of rotation.

Angular momentum is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction. The direction of the angular momentum vector is perpendicular to the plane formed by the moment of inertia and angular velocity vectors. This direction can be determined using the right-hand rule.

$$

where $\hat{\mathbf{P}}$ is the momentum operator, $m$ is the mass of the particle, $e$ is the charge of the particle, $c$ is the speed of light, and $\hat{\mathbf{A}}$ is the vector potential operator.

#### 2.3a Momentum Conservation Laws

The principle of conservation of momentum is a fundamental concept in classical mechanics. It states that the total momentum of a closed system remains constant unless acted upon by an external force. This principle is a direct consequence of Newton's second law of motion, which states that the force acting on a body is equal to the rate of change of its momentum.

Mathematically, the principle of conservation of momentum can be expressed as:

$$
\sum_{i} m_i v_i = constant
$$

where $m_i$ and $v_i$ are the mass and velocity of the $i$th particle, respectively, and the sum is over all particles in the system.

In the context of the Cauchy momentum equation, the principle of conservation of momentum can be applied to the left-hand side of the equation. If there are no external forces acting on the system, the left-hand side of the equation is equal to zero. This leads to the conclusion that the right-hand side of the equation, which represents the change in system momentum, is also equal to zero.

The principle of conservation of momentum is a powerful tool in the analysis of dynamic systems. It allows us to predict the behavior of a system under the action of internal forces alone, without the need to consider external forces. This is particularly useful in the study of systems of particles, where the interactions between particles can be complex and difficult to analyze.

#### 2.3b Applications in Collision Problems

The principle of conservation of momentum is particularly useful in the analysis of collision problems. In a collision, two or more particles interact with each other, exchanging momentum and possibly changing their velocities. The principle of conservation of momentum allows us to predict the outcome of a collision, given the initial velocities and masses of the particles involved.

Consider a simple one-dimensional collision between two particles, A and B, with masses $m_A$ and $m_B$, and initial velocities $v_A$ and $v_B$, respectively. If the collision is elastic, meaning that the total kinetic energy of the system is conserved, the final velocities of the particles can be calculated using the following equations:

$$
m_A v_A + m_B v_B = m_A v_A' + m_B v_B'
$$

$$
\frac{m_A v_A^2}{2} + \frac{m_B v_B^2}{2} = \frac{m_A v_A'^2}{2} + \frac{m_B v_B'^2}{2}
$$

where $v_A'$ and $v_B'$ are the final velocities of particles A and B, respectively.

These equations can be solved to find the final velocities of the particles, given the initial velocities and masses. This allows us to predict the outcome of the collision, including the direction in which the particles will move after the collision.

In the case of an inelastic collision, where some of the kinetic energy is lost in the form of heat or sound, the equations become more complex. However, the principle of conservation of momentum still applies, and can be used to find the final velocities of the particles.

#### 2.3c Applications in Rocket Propulsion

Consider a rocket in space with a mass $m_R$ and a velocity $v_R$. The rocket is ejecting a mass of fuel $m_F$ at a velocity $v_F$. If the ejection of the fuel is instantaneous, the conservation of momentum can be expressed as:

$$
m_R v_R + m_F v_F = constant
$$

This equation shows that the total momentum of the rocket and the fuel is conserved. The left-hand side represents the initial momentum of the rocket and the fuel, and the right-hand side represents the final momentum after the ejection of the fuel.

The change in momentum of the rocket, $\Delta p_R$, is equal to the negative of the change in momentum of the fuel, $\Delta p_F$. This means that the rocket experiences a force in the opposite direction to the ejected fuel. This force is the thrust generated by the rocket.

The thrust $T$ can be calculated using the equation:

$$
T = \Delta p_R = -\Delta p_F = -m_F v_F
$$

This equation shows that the thrust generated by the rocket is equal to the mass of the fuel times the velocity of the fuel. This is why rockets can generate large forces by ejecting small masses at high velocities.

#### 2.3b Impulse-Momentum Theorem

The Impulse-Momentum Theorem is a fundamental principle in the study of dynamics and vibration. It is a direct consequence of the principle of conservation of momentum and is particularly useful in the analysis of systems of particles.

The Impulse-Momentum Theorem can be stated as follows:

If a system of particles is subjected to a force $F(t)$ for a time interval $[a, b]$, the change in the total momentum of the system is given by:

$$
\Delta \mathbf{p} = \int_{a}^{b} \mathbf{F}(t) \, dt
$$

where $\mathbf{p}$ is the total momentum of the system, and $\mathbf{F}(t)$ is the force acting on the system.

This theorem is a powerful tool in the analysis of dynamic systems. It allows us to predict the change in momentum of a system under the action of a force, which can be particularly useful in the study of systems of particles.

In the context of the Cauchy momentum equation, the Impulse-Momentum Theorem can be applied to the right-hand side of the equation. If a system of particles is subjected to a force $F(t)$ for a time interval $[a, b]$, the change in the system momentum is given by the integral of the force over the time interval. This integral represents the impulse of the force on the system.

#### 2.4a Definition of Impact and Impulse

In classical mechanics, impact and impulse are two fundamental concepts that describe the change in momentum of an object. 

Impact is the sudden change in momentum of an object due to a force acting on it. It is a brief event that can have significant consequences on the motion of the object. The impact can be caused by a variety of forces, including collisions, friction, and gravity.

Impulse, on the other hand, is the change in momentum of an object over a period of time. It is a vector quantity, meaning it has both magnitude and direction. The impulse delivered by a force $F(t)$ acting for a time interval $[a, b]$ is given by the integral:

$$
\mathbf{J} = \int_{a}^{b} \mathbf{F}(t) \, dt
$$

The SI unit of impulse is the newton-second (N⋅s), and the dimensionally equivalent unit of momentum is the kilogram-metre per second (kg⋅m/s). The corresponding English engineering unit is the pound-second (lbf⋅s), and in the British Gravitational System, the unit is the slug-foot per second (slug⋅ft/s).

The impulse delivered by a varying force $F(t)$ is the integral of the force $F(t)$ with respect to time. This means that the impulse delivered by a force is equal to the area under the force-time graph.

The relationship between impact and impulse is described by Newton's second law of motion, which states that the rate of change of momentum of an object is equal to the resultant force $F$ acting on the object:

$$
\mathbf{F} = \frac{\mathbf{p_2} - \mathbf{p_1}}{\Delta t}
$$

where $\mathbf{p_1}$ and $\mathbf{p_2}$ are the initial and final momentums of the object, respectively, and $\Delta t$ is the time interval over which the force $F$ acts.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of impact and impulse in more detail, and discuss their applications in various fields.

$$
\mathbf{J} = \mathbf{p_2} - \mathbf{p_1}
$$

where $\mathbf{p_1}$ and $\mathbf{p_2}$ are the initial and final momentums of the object, respectively.

This theorem can be used to understand the relationship between impact and impulse. It is a direct consequence of Newton's second law of motion, which states that the rate of change of momentum of an object is equal to the resultant force $F$ acting on the object:

$$
\mathbf{F} = \frac{\mathbf{p_2} - \mathbf{p_1}}{\Delta t}
$$

where $\mathbf{p_1}$ and $\mathbf{p_2}$ are the initial and final momentums of the object, respectively, and $\Delta t$ is the time interval over which the force $F$ acts.

The impulse-momentum principle can be stated as follows:

> The impulse delivered by a force $F(t)$ acting for a time interval $[a, b]$ is equal to the change in momentum of the object over the same interval:

$$
\mathbf{J} = \mathbf{p_2} - \mathbf{p_1}
$$

This principle is particularly useful in situations where the force acting on an object is not constant. By integrating the force over the time interval, we can determine the impulse delivered, and then use the impulse-momentum principle to calculate the change in momentum.

The impulse-momentum principle has many practical applications in classical mechanics. For example, it can be used to analyze the motion of a rocket in space, where the rocket's engine provides a variable thrust over time. By calculating the impulse delivered by the engine, we can determine the change in momentum of the rocket, and hence its final velocity.

#### 2.4c Applications in Dynamics

The principles of impact and impulse are fundamental to the study of dynamics, particularly in the analysis of systems of particles. These principles are used to understand and predict the behavior of systems under various conditions, and to design and control systems for optimal performance.

One of the key applications of the impulse-momentum principle in dynamics is in the design and analysis of control systems. The Extended Kalman Filter (EKF), for instance, is a widely used control system that relies heavily on the principles of impact and impulse. The EKF is used in a variety of applications, including navigation, guidance, and control of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs).

The EKF operates on the principle of recursive estimation, where the state of the system is estimated based on a series of measurements. The impulse-momentum principle is used to model the dynamics of the system, and the Extended Kalman Filter is used to estimate the state of the system based on these dynamics.

The EKF model is given by:

$$
\dot{\mathbf{x}}(t) = f\bigl(\mathbf{x}(t), \mathbf{u}(t)\bigr) + \mathbf{w}(t) \quad \mathbf{w}(t) \sim \mathcal{N}\bigl(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{Q}(t)\bigr) \\
\mathbf{z}(t) = h\bigl(\mathbf{x}(t)\bigr) + \mathbf{v}(t) \quad \mathbf{v}(t) \sim \mathcal{N}\bigl(\mathbf{0},\mathbf{R}(t)\bigr)
$$

where $\mathbf{x}(t)$ is the state vector, $\mathbf{u}(t)$ is the control vector, $\mathbf{w}(t)$ is the process noise, $\mathbf{z}(t)$ is the measurement vector, and $\mathbf{v}(t)$ is the measurement noise. The functions $f(\cdot)$ and $h(\cdot)$ represent the system dynamics and measurement model, respectively. The matrices $\mathbf{Q}(t)$ and $\mathbf{R}(t)$ represent the process and measurement noise covariance matrices, respectively.

The Extended Kalman Filter uses the impulse-momentum principle to estimate the state of the system based on the EKF model. The impulse-momentum principle is used to model the dynamics of the system, and the Extended Kalman Filter is used to estimate the state of the system based on these dynamics.

$$

#### 2.5a Linear Momentum of Rigid Bodies

The concept of linear momentum is a fundamental principle in classical mechanics. It is a vector quantity that represents the linear motion of an object. For a system of particles, the linear momentum is the sum of the linear momenta of each particle. This principle is expressed mathematically as:

$$
\mathbf{p} = \sum_{i=1}^n m_i \mathbf{v}_i
$$

where $\mathbf{p}$ is the total linear momentum, $m_i$ is the mass of the $i$-th particle, and $\mathbf{v}_i$ is the velocity of the $i$-th particle.

In the context of rigid bodies, the linear momentum is a useful tool for analyzing the motion of the body. A rigid body is an idealized body in which deformation is neglected. The linear momentum of a rigid body is the sum of the linear momenta of all the particles that make up the body.

The linear momentum of a rigid body can be expressed in terms of the center of mass, which is the point at which the entire mass of the body is considered to be concentrated. The linear momentum of a rigid body relative to the center of mass is given by:

$$
\mathbf{p} = M \mathbf{V}
$$

where $M$ is the total mass of the body and $\mathbf{V}$ is the velocity of the center of mass.

The linear momentum of a rigid body relative to a fixed point $R$ is given by:

$$
\mathbf{p} = \sum_{i=1}^n m_i \left(\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{R}\right)
$$

where $\mathbf{r}_i$ is the position vector of the $i$-th particle relative to the fixed point $R$.

The linear momentum of a rigid body is a conserved quantity in a system where there are no external forces acting on the body. This principle is known as the conservation of linear momentum and is a fundamental concept in classical mechanics.

In the next section, we will explore the concept of angular momentum and its application in the study of rigid bodies.

#### 2.5b Angular Momentum of Rigid Bodies

The concept of angular momentum is another fundamental principle in classical mechanics, particularly in the study of rotational motion. It is a vector quantity that represents the rotational motion of an object. For a system of particles, the angular momentum is the sum of the angular momenta of each particle. This principle is expressed mathematically as:

$$
\mathbf{L} = \sum_{i=1}^n m_i \mathbf{r}_i \times \mathbf{v}_i
$$

where $\mathbf{L}$ is the total angular momentum, $m_i$ is the mass of the $i$-th particle, $\mathbf{r}_i$ is the position vector of the $i$-th particle relative to the center of mass, and $\mathbf{v}_i$ is the velocity of the $i$-th particle.

In the context of rigid bodies, the angular momentum is a useful tool for analyzing the rotational motion of the body. A rigid body is an idealized body in which deformation is neglected. The angular momentum of a rigid body is the sum of the angular momenta of all the particles that make up the body.

The angular momentum of a rigid body can be expressed in terms of the center of mass, which is the point at which the entire mass of the body is considered to be concentrated. The angular momentum of a rigid body relative to the center of mass is given by:

$$
\mathbf{L} = \sum_{i=1}^n m_i \left(\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{R}\right) \times \mathbf{V}
$$

where $\mathbf{R}$ is the position vector of the center of mass relative to a fixed point, and $\mathbf{V}$ is the velocity of the center of mass.

The angular momentum of a rigid body relative to a fixed point $R$ is given by:

$$
\mathbf{L} = \sum_{i=1}^n m_i \left(\mathbf{r}_i - \mathbf{R}\right) \times \mathbf{v}_i
$$

where $\mathbf{v}_i$ is the velocity of the $i$-th particle relative to the fixed point $R$.

The angular momentum of a rigid body is a conserved quantity in a system where there are no external torques acting on the body. This principle is known as the conservation of angular momentum and is a fundamental concept in classical mechanics.

\sum_{i=1}^n m_i \mathbf{v}_i = \text{constant}
$$

where $m_i$ is the mass of the $i$-th particle, $\mathbf{v}_i$ is the velocity of the $i$-th particle, and the sum is over all $n$ particles in the system.

$$

where $\mathbf{r}_i$ is the position vector of the $i$-th particle relative to the center of mass, $\mathbf{v}_i$ is the velocity of the $i$-th particle, and $\mathbf{R}$ is the position vector of the center of mass.
